nistRequirement: a. Develop, document, and disseminate to organizational personnel or roles the policies and procedures needed to satisfy the security requirements for the protection of CUI. b. Review and update policies and procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].

settings.description: Microsoft Purview Compliance Manager provides structured assessment templates for NIST 800-171 Rev 3 that guide organizations in documenting policies and procedures across all security control families. The assessment tracks implementation status, provides improvement actions, and maintains documentation of organizational policies.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Sign in to Microsoft Purview portal (compliance.microsoft.com) as Compliance Administrator
2. Navigate to Compliance Manager > Assessments
3. Select 'Create assessment' and choose NIST SP 800-171 Rev 3 template
4. Configure assessment group and name (e.g., 'NIST 800-171 Rev 3 Implementation')
5. Assign roles (Assessors, Contributors, Readers) to appropriate personnel
6. Document policies and procedures for each control family in improvement actions
7. Upload policy documents as evidence
8. Set review schedule (e.g., annually) for policy updates
9. Track completion status and compliance score

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Compliance Manager provides a structured framework for documenting, tracking, and maintaining organizational policies and procedures across all NIST 800-171 security requirements. It includes workflow capabilities for policy review cycles and evidence management.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Develop, document, and disseminate policies and procedures; Review and update at defined frequency

settings.description: Information Protection policies in Purview define and enforce data classification, labeling, and protection requirements. These policies document how CUI and sensitive information should be handled throughout its lifecycle, supporting the policy and procedure requirements for data protection.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Navigate to Microsoft Purview portal > Information Protection
2. Create sensitivity labels for CUI classification (e.g., Confidential, Highly Confidential)
3. Configure label policies defining:
   - Mandatory labeling requirements
   - Default labels for documents and emails
   - Label inheritance settings
   - Encryption and access control requirements
4. Document policy scope and applicability in policy descriptions
5. Assign policies to appropriate user groups
6. Enable label policy analytics to monitor compliance
7. Establish review cycle (minimum annually) for policy updates
8. Publish policies to users with training materials

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Information Protection policies document and enforce organizational requirements for handling CUI, implementing the policy framework required by NIST 800-171. The policies are disseminated automatically to users through the M365 environment.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Document and disseminate policies for protection of CUI

settings.displayName: Azure AD Conditional Access Security Policies
settings.description: Conditional Access policies define and enforce access control requirements for CUI systems. These policies document organizational requirements for authentication, device compliance, and access conditions, implementing the access control policy framework required by NIST 800-171.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Sign in to Azure Portal (portal.azure.com) as Global Administrator
2. Navigate to Azure Active Directory > Security > Conditional Access
3. Create baseline security policies:
   - Policy 1: Require MFA for all users
   - Policy 2: Block legacy authentication
   - Policy 3: Require compliant or hybrid joined devices
4. Document each policy with clear descriptions and rationale
5. Configure policy to report-only mode initially for testing
6. Test policies with pilot group
7. Enable policies (set to 'On')
8. Document policy review schedule (recommend quarterly)
9. Export policy configurations as documentation
10. Store policy documentation in secure location accessible to auditors

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Conditional Access policies document and enforce organizational access control requirements, forming a key component of the security policy framework. CIS Benchmark Section 1.1 requires documented authentication and access policies.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Develop and document policies for access control (references 03.01.02 Access Enforcement)

settings.description: Device compliance policies define and enforce organizational requirements for device security configuration. These policies document minimum security standards that devices must meet to access CUI, supporting the policy framework for system and device protection.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Sign in to Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center (endpoint.microsoft.com)
2. Navigate to Devices > Compliance policies > Policies
3. Create compliance policy for each platform (Windows, iOS, Android):
   - Windows 10/11: Require BitLocker, password requirements, firewall enabled
   - iOS/iPadOS: Require passcode, jailbreak detection
   - Android: Require encryption, Google Play Protect
4. Document policy settings and rationale in policy description
5. Configure compliance actions (mark non-compliant, notify users)
6. Assign policies to appropriate device groups
7. Test policies with pilot devices
8. Monitor compliance status in Intune dashboard
9. Schedule quarterly policy review
10. Document exceptions and approved deviations

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Device compliance policies document organizational requirements for endpoint security, implementing the policy framework for device protection required by NIST 800-171. CIS Benchmark Section 7.3 requires documented device compliance policies for all platforms.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Develop and document policies for device and endpoint security

settings.description: Security baseline policies provide Microsoft-recommended security configurations that document and enforce organizational security standards. These pre-configured policies implement industry best practices and document the security requirements for Windows devices processing CUI.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Navigate to Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center
2. Go to Endpoint security > Security baselines
3. Select 'Windows 10 and later Security Baseline'
4. Click 'Create profile'
5. Configure baseline settings:
   - Review and accept default settings (Microsoft recommended)
   - Customize settings if organizational requirements differ
   - Document any deviations from baseline with justification
6. Name the profile clearly (e.g., 'Windows Security Baseline - NIST 800-171')
7. Add detailed description documenting purpose and scope
8. Assign to Windows device groups
9. Monitor deployment status and compliance
10. Schedule annual baseline review to adopt updated versions
11. Export baseline configuration for documentation

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Security baselines provide comprehensive documented security configurations based on Microsoft and industry best practices. They implement the security policy framework required by NIST 800-171 with pre-defined, tested configurations. CIS Benchmark Section 7.6 recommends security baseline configuration.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Document security procedures and standards for system configuration

settings.description: Retention policies document and enforce organizational requirements for information lifecycle management. These policies define how long CUI and other information must be retained, supporting compliance with record retention requirements and documenting information management procedures.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Navigate to Microsoft Purview portal > Data Lifecycle Management
2. Go to Microsoft 365 > Retention policies
3. Create retention policy for CUI:
   - Click 'New retention policy'
   - Name: 'CUI Retention Policy'
   - Choose locations (Exchange, SharePoint, OneDrive, Teams)
   - Define retention period (e.g., 7 years for CUI)
   - Configure retention actions (retain and delete, or retain only)
4. Document policy scope and business justification
5. Create additional policies for different information types
6. Assign policies using adaptive scopes or specific locations
7. Test policy with sample content
8. Enable policy
9. Monitor retention status
10. Schedule annual policy review
11. Document policy in organizational records management plan

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Retention policies document organizational procedures for information lifecycle management, implementing the policy framework for records management and information protection. These policies address requirements in multiple NIST families (MP, SI).
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Document procedures for information management and retention

primarySources: CISA M365 Secure Configuration Baseline v1.0
metadata.implementationNotes: Control 03.15.01 requires documented policies and procedures across all security control families. The settings above provide the M365 infrastructure to create, document, maintain, and disseminate these policies. Organizations must still create the actual policy content to address each control family's requirements.
